commit_list.message:
Support Rails 2.3 / Rack 1.1 array-style cookies (For real this time)

I neglected to account for the fact that Rails monkeypatches Array to
have #split method, so although it passed the tests, it didn't actually
work with a Rails 2.3.x project.
commit_list.repo_description: A simple Rack middleware to enforce ssl connections

commit_list.message:
Support Rails 2.3 / Rack 1.1 array-style cookies

Rack 1.1 / Rails 2.3.10 and higher (but not Rails 3.0 or later versions
of Rack) treat the Set-Cookie header as an array instead of a string.

This simply allows us to process those headers properly for these
versions.

Fix use of Javascript reserved words as variable names

Attempts to use YUICompressor on this plugin were failing because it
used "int" as a variable name. That's technically a reserved word in
Javascript, and confused YUICompressor.

BUG: Don't crash if we receive a node with no kernel attributes set
Use builder + views
Use builder for generating the views; support search by environment, domain, and arbitrary search
Make ChefRundeck a module, with a Server class inside it.
Fix up rspec to actually be working
Switch from Jewler to Bundler for building gems
Allow overriding the username on a per-node basis using node attribute

Make the --web_ui_url parameter optional.

Also, allow overriding the node's edit_url by setting a node attribute.

Allow filtering the entire node resource collection by environment

GET / gets all nodes regardless of environment
GET /:environment gets just a particular environment
Move to using bundler

commit_list.message:
Initial attempt at pageable incident list

* Upgrade Backbone to 1.1.x releases
* Convert collections to using PageableCollection
* Configure PageableCollection to (mostly) interact with PagerDuty's
  paging model based on offsets vs. pages

At this point I've proven the paging can work, by visualizing only the
100-200th most recent incidents, but this still needs work to actually
load more than one page of results and render that.

commit_list.message:
Enforce socket timeout on connect

Earlier changes to the memcache client changed the timeout mechanism
from using the (somewhat unreliable) Timeout or SystemTimer libraries to
using low-level non-blocking I/O. This works great - assuming the client
connects in the first place.

This change re-introduces the timeout mechanism and wraps the socket
creation - if you try to connect to a memcache server that's
down/rebooting/whatever, it will timeout sooner than the OS-specified
timeout for the socket.

NOOP: Lower logging level for super-verbose messages

running at the debug log level) that the rest of the logs are drowned
out in the noise. They never make sense to run in production, so I'm
changing their log level to trace.
